trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Search | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Search | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Search is a new service that allows you to embed search functionality into custom applications.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Search is a new service that allows you to embed search functionality into custom applications.

trans-unit.source: It provides the search engine and storage for your data, which you access and manage using a .NET library or a REST API.
trans-unit.target: It provides the search engine and storage for your data, which you access and manage using a .NET library or a REST API.

trans-unit.source: This article gets you started with the Azure Search REST API.
trans-unit.target: This article gets you started with the Azure Search REST API.

trans-unit.source: An alternative approach for .NET developers is to use the Azure Search.NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: An alternative approach for .NET developers is to use the Azure Search.NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search in .NET</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>How to use the Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Search in .NET</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>How to use the Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: Completing this tutorial requires an <link><linkText>Azure subscription</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Completing this tutorial requires an <link><linkText>Azure subscription</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you aren't ready to sign up for a trial subscription, you can skip this tutorial and opt for <link><linkText>Try Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> instead.
trans-unit.target: If you aren't ready to sign up for a trial subscription, you can skip this tutorial and opt for <link><linkText>Try Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> instead.

trans-unit.source: This alternative option gives you Azure Search with an ASP.NET Web app for free - one hour per session - no subscription required.
trans-unit.target: This alternative option gives you Azure Search with an ASP.NET Web app for free - one hour per session - no subscription required.

trans-unit.source: Start with the free service
trans-unit.target: Start with the free service

trans-unit.source: As an administrator, you can add Search service to an existing subscription at no cost when choosing the shared service, or at a reduced rate when opting in for dedicated resources.
trans-unit.target: As an administrator, you can add Search service to an existing subscription at no cost when choosing the shared service, or at a reduced rate when opting in for dedicated resources.

trans-unit.source: Subscribers automatically get free access to a shared, multitenant Search service that you can use for learning purposes, proof-of-concept testing, or small development search projects.
trans-unit.target: Subscribers automatically get free access to a shared, multitenant Search service that you can use for learning purposes, proof-of-concept testing, or small development search projects.

trans-unit.source: Sign up for the free version using these steps.
trans-unit.target: Sign up for the free version using these steps.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.

trans-unit.source: Notice that this URL takes you to the Preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Notice that this URL takes you to the Preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Using the Preview portal is a requirement.
trans-unit.target: Using the Preview portal is a requirement.

trans-unit.source: Click New at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click New at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click Data + Storage | Search.
trans-unit.target: Click Data + Storage | Search.

trans-unit.source: Type a lower-case service name to use in the service URL, avoiding spaces, and staying within the 15 character string limit.
trans-unit.target: Type a lower-case service name to use in the service URL, avoiding spaces, and staying within the 15 character string limit.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow in Pricing Tier to select a pricing option.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow in Pricing Tier to select a pricing option.

trans-unit.source: Choose FREE and then click SELECT at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Choose FREE and then click SELECT at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: The free version offers enough capacity to try out tutorials and write proof-of-concept code, but is not intended for production applications.
trans-unit.target: The free version offers enough capacity to try out tutorials and write proof-of-concept code, but is not intended for production applications.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow in Resource Group to pick an existing group or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow in Resource Group to pick an existing group or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Resource groups are containers for services and resources used for a common purpose.
trans-unit.target: Resource groups are containers for services and resources used for a common purpose.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you're building a custom search application based on Azure Search, Azure Websites, Azure BLOB storage, you could create a resource group that keeps these services together in the portal management pages.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you're building a custom search application based on Azure Search, Azure Websites, Azure BLOB storage, you could create a resource group that keeps these services together in the portal management pages.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow in Subscription if you have multiple subscriptions and you want to use a different subscription for this search service.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow in Subscription if you have multiple subscriptions and you want to use a different subscription for this search service.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow in Location to choose a data center region.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow in Location to choose a data center region.

trans-unit.source: In this preview, you can choose from West US, East US, North Europe, and Southeast Asia.
trans-unit.target: In this preview, you can choose from West US, East US, North Europe, and Southeast Asia.

trans-unit.source: Later, when other regions are online, choose one region for the service you are creating.
trans-unit.target: Later, when other regions are online, choose one region for the service you are creating.

trans-unit.source: Distributing resources across multiple data centers will not be a supported configuration for public preview.
trans-unit.target: Distributing resources across multiple data centers will not be a supported configuration for public preview.

trans-unit.source: Click CREATE to provision the service.
trans-unit.target: Click CREATE to provision the service.

trans-unit.source: Notice that CREATE is enabled only after you fill in all required values.
trans-unit.target: Notice that CREATE is enabled only after you fill in all required values.

trans-unit.source: In a few minutes, the service is created.
trans-unit.target: In a few minutes, the service is created.

trans-unit.source: You can return to the configuration settings to get the URL or api-keys.
trans-unit.target: You can return to the configuration settings to get the URL or api-keys.

trans-unit.source: Connections to your Search service requires that you have both the URL and an api-key to authenticate the call.
trans-unit.target: Connections to your Search service requires that you have both the URL and an api-key to authenticate the call.

trans-unit.source: Here's how to quickly find these values:
trans-unit.target: Here's how to quickly find these values:

trans-unit.source: Go to Home to open the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Go to Home to open the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Click the Search service to open the service dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Click the Search service to open the service dashboard.

trans-unit.source: On the service dashboard, you'll see tiles for PROPERTIES and KEYS, and usage information that shows resource usage at a glance.
trans-unit.target: On the service dashboard, you'll see tiles for PROPERTIES and KEYS, and usage information that shows resource usage at a glance.

trans-unit.source: Continue on to <link><linkText>Test service operations</linkText><title></title></link> for instructions on how to connect to the service using these values.
trans-unit.target: Continue on to <link><linkText>Test service operations</linkText><title></title></link> for instructions on how to connect to the service using these values.

trans-unit.source: Upgrade to standard search
trans-unit.target: Upgrade to standard search

trans-unit.source: Standard search gets you dedicated resources in an Azure data center that can be used only by you.
trans-unit.target: Standard search gets you dedicated resources in an Azure data center that can be used only by you.

trans-unit.source: Search workloads require both storage and service replicas.
trans-unit.target: Search workloads require both storage and service replicas.

trans-unit.source: When you sign up for standard search, you can optimize service configuration to use more of whichever resource is the most important to your scenario.
trans-unit.target: When you sign up for standard search, you can optimize service configuration to use more of whichever resource is the most important to your scenario.

trans-unit.source: Having dedicated resources will give you more scale and better performance, but not additional features.
trans-unit.target: Having dedicated resources will give you more scale and better performance, but not additional features.

trans-unit.source: Both shared and standard search offer the same features.
trans-unit.target: Both shared and standard search offer the same features.

trans-unit.source: To use standard search, create a new Search service, choosing the Standard pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: To use standard search, create a new Search service, choosing the Standard pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: Notice that upgrade is not an in-place upgrade of the free version.
trans-unit.target: Notice that upgrade is not an in-place upgrade of the free version.

trans-unit.source: Switching to standard, with its potential for scale, requires a new service.
trans-unit.target: Switching to standard, with its potential for scale, requires a new service.

trans-unit.source: You will need to reload the indexes and documents used by your search application.
trans-unit.target: You will need to reload the indexes and documents used by your search application.

trans-unit.source: Setting up dedicated resources can take a while (15 minutes or longer).
trans-unit.target: Setting up dedicated resources can take a while (15 minutes or longer).

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create a new service with Pricing Tier set to Standard
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create a new service with Pricing Tier set to Standard

trans-unit.source: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.

trans-unit.source: Click New at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click New at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: From the Gallery, click Data + Storage | Search.
trans-unit.target: From the Gallery, click Data + Storage | Search.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the service configuration settings and then click CREATE.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the service configuration settings and then click CREATE.

trans-unit.source: In Pricing Tier to select a pricing option.
trans-unit.target: In Pricing Tier to select a pricing option.

trans-unit.source: Choose STANDARD and then click SELECT at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Choose STANDARD and then click SELECT at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Adjust search units based on scale requirements
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Adjust search units based on scale requirements

trans-unit.source: Standard search starts with one replica and partition each, but can be easily re-scaled at higher resource levels.
trans-unit.target: Standard search starts with one replica and partition each, but can be easily re-scaled at higher resource levels.

trans-unit.source: Once the service is created, return to the service dashboard, click the Scale tile.
trans-unit.target: Once the service is created, return to the service dashboard, click the Scale tile.

trans-unit.source: Use the sliders to add replicas, partitions, or both.
trans-unit.target: Use the sliders to add replicas, partitions, or both.

trans-unit.source: Additional replicas and partitions are billed in search units.
trans-unit.target: Additional replicas and partitions are billed in search units.

trans-unit.source: The total search units required to support any particular resource configuration is shown on the page, as you add resources.
trans-unit.target: The total search units required to support any particular resource configuration is shown on the page, as you add resources.

trans-unit.source: You can check <link><linkText>Pricing Details</linkText><title></title></link> to get the per-unit billing information.
trans-unit.target: You can check <link><linkText>Pricing Details</linkText><title></title></link> to get the per-unit billing information.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link> for help in deciding how to configure partition and replica combinations.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link> for help in deciding how to configure partition and replica combinations.

trans-unit.source: Test service operations
trans-unit.target: Test service operations

trans-unit.source: Confirming that your service is operational and accessible from a client application is the final step in configuring Search.
trans-unit.target: Confirming that your service is operational and accessible from a client application is the final step in configuring Search.

trans-unit.source: This procedure uses Fiddler, available as a <link><linkText>free download from Telerik</linkText><title></title></link>, to issue HTTP requests and view responses.
trans-unit.target: This procedure uses Fiddler, available as a <link><linkText>free download from Telerik</linkText><title></title></link>, to issue HTTP requests and view responses.

trans-unit.source: By using Fiddler, you can test the API immediately, without having to write any code.
trans-unit.target: By using Fiddler, you can test the API immediately, without having to write any code.

trans-unit.source: The following procedure works for both shared and standard search.
trans-unit.target: The following procedure works for both shared and standard search.

trans-unit.source: In the steps below, you'll create an index, upload documents, query the index, and then query the system for service information.
trans-unit.target: In the steps below, you'll create an index, upload documents, query the index, and then query the system for service information.

trans-unit.source: Create an index
trans-unit.target: Create an index

trans-unit.source: Start Fiddler.
trans-unit.target: Start Fiddler.

trans-unit.source: On the File menu, turn off Capture Traffic to hide extraneous HTTP activity that is unrelated to the current task.
trans-unit.target: On the File menu, turn off Capture Traffic to hide extraneous HTTP activity that is unrelated to the current task.

trans-unit.source: On the Composer tab, you'll formulate a request that looks like this:
trans-unit.target: On the Composer tab, you'll formulate a request that looks like this:

trans-unit.source: Select PUT.
trans-unit.target: Select PUT.

trans-unit.source: Enter a URL that specifies the service URL (which you can find on the Properties page), request attributes and the api-version.
trans-unit.target: Enter a URL that specifies the service URL (which you can find on the Properties page), request attributes and the api-version.

trans-unit.source: A few pointers to keep in mind:
trans-unit.target: A few pointers to keep in mind:

trans-unit.source: Use HTTPS as the prefix
trans-unit.target: Use HTTPS as the prefix

trans-unit.source: Request attribute is "/indexes/hotels".
trans-unit.target: Request attribute is "/indexes/hotels".

trans-unit.source: This tells Search to create an index named 'hotels'.
trans-unit.target: This tells Search to create an index named 'hotels'.

trans-unit.source: Api-version is lower-case, specified as "?api-version=2015-02-28".
trans-unit.target: Api-version is lower-case, specified as "?api-version=2015-02-28".

trans-unit.source: API versions are important because Azure Search deploys updates regularly.
trans-unit.target: API versions are important because Azure Search deploys updates regularly.

trans-unit.source: On rare occasions, a service update may introduce a breaking change to the API.
trans-unit.target: On rare occasions, a service update may introduce a breaking change to the API.

trans-unit.source: Using API versions, you can continue to use your existing version and upgrade to the newer one when it is convenient.
trans-unit.target: Using API versions, you can continue to use your existing version and upgrade to the newer one when it is convenient.

trans-unit.source: The full URL should look similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: The full URL should look similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: Specify the request header, replacing the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: Specify the request header, replacing the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: In Request Body, paste in the fields that make up the index definition.
trans-unit.target: In Request Body, paste in the fields that make up the index definition.

trans-unit.source: Click Execute.
trans-unit.target: Click Execute.

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds, you should see an HTTP 201 response in the session list, indicating the index was created successfully.
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds, you should see an HTTP 201 response in the session list, indicating the index was created successfully.

trans-unit.source: If you get HTTP 504, verify the URL specifies HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: If you get HTTP 504, verify the URL specifies HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: If you see HTTP 400 or 404, check the request body to verify there were no copy-paste errors.
trans-unit.target: If you see HTTP 400 or 404, check the request body to verify there were no copy-paste errors.

trans-unit.source: An HTTP 403 typically indicates a problem with the api-key (either an invalid key or a syntax problem with how the api-key is specified).
trans-unit.target: An HTTP 403 typically indicates a problem with the api-key (either an invalid key or a syntax problem with how the api-key is specified).

trans-unit.source: Load documents
trans-unit.target: Load documents

trans-unit.source: On the Composer tab, your request to post documents will look like the following.
trans-unit.target: On the Composer tab, your request to post documents will look like the following.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request contains the search data for 4 hotels.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request contains the search data for 4 hotels.

trans-unit.source: Select POST.
trans-unit.target: Select POST.

trans-unit.source: Enter a URL that starts with HTTPS, followed by your service URL, followed by "/indexes/<html></html>/docs/index?api-version=2015-02-28". The full URL should look similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: Enter a URL that starts with HTTPS, followed by your service URL, followed by "/indexes/<html></html>/docs/index?api-version=2015-02-28". The full URL should look similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: Request Header should be the same as before.
trans-unit.target: Request Header should be the same as before.

trans-unit.source: Remember that you replaced the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: Remember that you replaced the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: The Request Body contains four documents to be added to the hotels index.
trans-unit.target: The Request Body contains four documents to be added to the hotels index.

trans-unit.source: Click Execute.
trans-unit.target: Click Execute.

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds, you should see an HTTP 200 response in the session list.
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds, you should see an HTTP 200 response in the session list.

trans-unit.source: This indicates the documents were created successfully.
trans-unit.target: This indicates the documents were created successfully.

trans-unit.source: If you get a 207, at least one document failed to upload.
trans-unit.target: If you get a 207, at least one document failed to upload.

trans-unit.source: If you get a 404, you have a syntax error in either the header or body of the request.
trans-unit.target: If you get a 404, you have a syntax error in either the header or body of the request.

trans-unit.source: Query the index
trans-unit.target: Query the index

trans-unit.source: Now that an index and documents are loaded, you can issue queries against them.
trans-unit.target: Now that an index and documents are loaded, you can issue queries against them.

trans-unit.source: On the Composer tab, a GET command that queries your service will look similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: On the Composer tab, a GET command that queries your service will look similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Select GET.
trans-unit.target: Select GET.

trans-unit.source: Enter a URL that starts with HTTPS, followed by your service URL, followed by "/indexes/<html></html>/docs?", followed by query parameters. By way of example, use the following URL, replacing the sample host name with one that is valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: Enter a URL that starts with HTTPS, followed by your service URL, followed by "/indexes/<html></html>/docs?", followed by query parameters. By way of example, use the following URL, replacing the sample host name with one that is valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: This query searches on the term “motel” and retrieves facet categories for ratings.
trans-unit.target: This query searches on the term “motel” and retrieves facet categories for ratings.

trans-unit.source: Request Header should be the same as before.
trans-unit.target: Request Header should be the same as before.

trans-unit.source: Remember that you replaced the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: Remember that you replaced the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: The response code should be 200, and the response output should look similar to the following illustration.
trans-unit.target: The response code should be 200, and the response output should look similar to the following illustration.

trans-unit.source: The following example query is from the <link><linkText>Search Index operation (Azure Search API)</linkText><title></title></link> on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: The following example query is from the <link><linkText>Search Index operation (Azure Search API)</linkText><title></title></link> on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Many of the example queries in this topic include spaces, which are not allowed in Fiddler.
trans-unit.target: Many of the example queries in this topic include spaces, which are not allowed in Fiddler.

trans-unit.source: Replace each space with a + character before pasting in the query string before attempting the query in Fiddler:
trans-unit.target: Replace each space with a + character before pasting in the query string before attempting the query in Fiddler:

trans-unit.source: Before spaces are replaced:
trans-unit.target: Before spaces are replaced:

trans-unit.source: After spaces are replaced with +:
trans-unit.target: After spaces are replaced with +:

trans-unit.source: Query the system
trans-unit.target: Query the system

trans-unit.source: You can also query the system to get document counts and storage consumption.
trans-unit.target: You can also query the system to get document counts and storage consumption.

trans-unit.source: On the Composer tab, your request will look similar to the following, and the response will return a count for the number of documents and space used.
trans-unit.target: On the Composer tab, your request will look similar to the following, and the response will return a count for the number of documents and space used.

trans-unit.source: Select GET.
trans-unit.target: Select GET.

trans-unit.source: Enter a URL that includes your service URL, followed by "/indexes/hotels/stats?api-version=2015-02-28":
trans-unit.target: Enter a URL that includes your service URL, followed by "/indexes/hotels/stats?api-version=2015-02-28":

trans-unit.source: Specify the request header, replacing the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: Specify the request header, replacing the host and api-key with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: Leave the request body empty.
trans-unit.target: Leave the request body empty.

trans-unit.source: Click Execute.
trans-unit.target: Click Execute.

trans-unit.source: You should see an HTTP 200 status code in the session list.
trans-unit.target: You should see an HTTP 200 status code in the session list.

trans-unit.source: Select the entry posted for your command.
trans-unit.target: Select the entry posted for your command.

trans-unit.source: Click the Inspectors tab | Headers, and select the JSON format.
trans-unit.target: Click the Inspectors tab | Headers, and select the JSON format.

trans-unit.source: You should see the document count and storage size (in KB).
trans-unit.target: You should see the document count and storage size (in KB).

trans-unit.source: Explore Search service dashboard
trans-unit.target: Explore Search service dashboard

trans-unit.source: If you need a refresher on where to find the configuration pages, follow these steps to locate the service dashboard.
trans-unit.target: If you need a refresher on where to find the configuration pages, follow these steps to locate the service dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link> using your existing subscription.

trans-unit.source: Click Home and then click the tile for your Search service.
trans-unit.target: Click Home and then click the tile for your Search service.

trans-unit.source: Clicking the tile opens the service dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Clicking the tile opens the service dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Notice that Start, Stop, and Delete commands are at the top.
trans-unit.target: Notice that Start, Stop, and Delete commands are at the top.

trans-unit.source: Notice the service URL is near the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Notice the service URL is near the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: You will need this URL in to connect to your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: You will need this URL in to connect to your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: Click the KEYS icon to view the api-keys.
trans-unit.target: Click the KEYS icon to view the api-keys.

trans-unit.source: You will need an Admin key to authenticate to the service.
trans-unit.target: You will need an Admin key to authenticate to the service.

trans-unit.source: You can use either the primary or secondary.
trans-unit.target: You can use either the primary or secondary.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can create query keys for read-only access to the service.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can create query keys for read-only access to the service.

trans-unit.source: Try it out
trans-unit.target: Try it out

trans-unit.source: Ready for the next step?
trans-unit.target: Ready for the next step?

trans-unit.source: The following links take you to additional material that shows you how to build and manage search applications that use Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: The following links take you to additional material that shows you how to build and manage search applications that use Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Cloud Cover episode 152: Generate an index in Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Cloud Cover episode 152: Generate an index in Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link>
